title: Light's Criteria for Exudative Effusions
description: Determines if pleural fluid is exudative or transudative by comparing pleural fluid and serum protein and LDH levels

parameters.name: serum_protein
parameters.description: Total serum protein level in g/dL

parameters.name: pleural_fluid_protein
parameters.description: Pleural fluid protein level in g/dL

parameters.name: serum_ldh
parameters.description: Serum lactate dehydrogenase level in U/L

parameters.name: pleural_fluid_ldh
parameters.description: Pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase level in U/L

parameters.name: serum_ldh_upper_normal
parameters.description: Upper limit of normal for serum LDH (typically 222 U/L)

result.name: effusion_type
result.description: Classification of pleural effusion as exudative or transudative

ranges.interpretation: Effusion is transudative. None of Light's criteria are met. This suggests conditions like congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, or nephrotic syndrome. Focus treatment on underlying condition.
Effusion is exudative. At least one of Light's criteria is met. This suggests conditions like pneumonia, malignancy, tuberculosis, or pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic workup is indicated.

references: Light RW, Macgregor MI, Luchsinger PC, Ball WC Jr. Pleural effusions: the diagnostic separation of transudates and exudates. Ann Intern Med. 1972 Oct;77(4):507-13. doi: 10.7326/0003-4819-77-4-507.

Heffner JE, Brown LK, Barbieri C, DeLeo JM. Pleural fluid chemical analysis in parapneumonic effusions. A meta-analysis. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 1995 Jun;151(6):1700-8. doi: 10.1164/ajrccm.151.6.7767510.
Porcel JM, Light RW. Diagnostic approach to pleural effusion in adults. Am Fam Physician. 2006 Apr 1;73(7):1211-20.
formula: Exudate if any one of: (1) Pleural fluid protein / Serum protein > 0.5, (2) Pleural fluid LDH / Serum LDH > 0.6, (3) Pleural fluid LDH > (2/3 Ã— Upper limit normal serum LDH)
notes: Only ONE criterion needs to be met for exudate classification
Diuretic therapy can cause 'pseudoexudates' (transudates meeting exudate criteria)
Consider serum-pleural fluid protein gradient >3.1 g/dL or albumin gradient >1.2 g/dL to identify pseudoexudates
Most commonly used criteria for pleural effusion classification since 1972
